G.L. c. 218, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������� as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Venue is proper in the Newton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, �������������������������������������������������������������� as the incident giving rise to this claim occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

*Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held defendants liable for injuries caused by their failure to properly control their dogs, including cases involving unleashed dogs, as in *Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913) (dog owner liable for injuries caused indirectly by dog’s conduct); *Munn v. Hotchkiss*, 247 Mass. 79 (1923) (failure to restrain dog may constitute negligence where injury is reasonably foreseeable); *Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161 (1994) (requiring dog owners to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm caused by dogs).
*Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913).case_name: Bosquet v. Worcester Consolidated Street Railway Co.
*Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt in *Blais v. Berean* concerns a street railway accident involving a boy on a bicycle and a trolley car, focusing on the boy’s due care and the motorman’s negligence. There is no discussion of dogs, dog ownership, or liability for injuries caused by dogs. Accordingly, this case does not support the proposition that Massachusetts courts have held dog owners liable for injuries caused by their failure to control their dogs.
*Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913).relevant_excerpt: “We also think that there was evidence of negligence on the part of the motorman. The corner was or could be found to be a dangerous place. And it was for the jury to say whether the motorman exercised that degree of care which he ought to have exercised in approaching it and in attempting to avoid a collision… The jury may have thought… that if he had exercised proper care he would have seen the plaintiff and been able to avoid the accident.”

*Munn v. Hotchkiss*, 247 Mass. 79 (1923).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held defendants liable for injuries caused by their failure to properly control their dogs, including cases involving unleashed dogs, as in *Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913) (dog owner liable for injuries caused indirectly by dog’s conduct); *Munn v. Hotchkiss*, 247 Mass. 79 (1923) (failure to restrain dog may constitute negligence where injury is reasonably foreseeable); *Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161 (1994) (requiring dog owners to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm caused by dogs).
*Munn v. Hotchkiss*, 247 Mass. 79 (1923).support_reasoning: This opinion has nothing to do with dogs, animal control, or duties of dog owners. It concerns vicarious liability and scope of employment for a chauffeur operating a motor vehicle. Citing Munn v. Hotchkiss for the proposition that failure to restrain a dog may constitute negligence is inaccurate and unrelated to the actual holding or reasoning of the case.
*Munn v. Hotchkiss*, 247 Mass. 79 (1923).relevant_excerpt: "The only remaining issue, raised in substance by the requests numbered 4, 5, 7, 9 and 10, is whether there was evidence warranting a finding that Maranis, an admitted employee, was acting within the scope of his employment at the time of the accident."

*Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held defendants liable for injuries caused by their failure to properly control their dogs, including cases involving unleashed dogs, as in *Blais v. Berean* 215 Mass. 538 (1913) (dog owner liable for injuries caused indirectly by dog’s conduct); *Munn v. Hotchkiss*, 247 Mass. 79 (1923) (failure to restrain dog may constitute negligence where injury is reasonably foreseeable); *Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161 (1994) (requiring dog owners to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm caused by dogs).
*Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161.case_name: Judson v. ESSEX AGRICULTURAL & TECHNICAL INSTITUTE
*Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion in Fitzgerald v. Connolly does not address dog ownership, dog control, or any duty of care relating to injuries caused by dogs. It concerns whether a vocational school had a duty to inspect a student’s workplace and ensure workers’ compensation coverage. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that Massachusetts requires dog owners to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm caused by dogs.
*Fitzgerald v. Connolly*, 418 Mass. 161.relevant_excerpt: We hold that EATI had no duty to inspect the plaintiff’s work place or to ascertain that Bradvue provided workers’ compensation insurance for the plaintiff.

G.L. c. 140, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Defendant further breached his duty under G.L. c. 140, ���������������������������������������������������, which requires dog owners to control their animals.

*Walsh v. Ogorzalek*, 372 Mass. 271 (197.proposition: Failure to comply with an applicable statutory duty constitutes prima facie evidence of negligence under Massachusetts law as outlined in *Walsh v. Ogorzalek*, 372 Mass. 271 (1977).
*Walsh v. Ogorzalek*, 372 Mass. 271 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion in Walsh v. Ogorzalek deals exclusively with tolling of the statute of limitations under G.L. c. 260, § 9 when a defendant is a nonresident amenable to service under nonresident motorist or long-arm statutes. It does not address negligence standards or the evidentiary effect of violating a statutory duty, nor does it discuss prima facie evidence of negligence. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that statutory violations constitute prima facie negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Walsh v. Ogorzalek*, 372 Mass. 271 (197.relevant_excerpt: "We consider first the purpose of the tolling statute: to prevent a potential defendant from insulating himself from liability by placing himself for a time beyond the reaches of the law for purposes of service.... We construe the words of c. 260, § 9, which refer to a defendant who 'resides out of the commonwealth,' as describing a person who by reason of non-residence is beyond the jurisdiction and process of the court."
